sentences.sentence: While busily reading, she was suddenly startled( 惊吓的 ) by the sound of the door-bell.
To her utter( 彻底的 ) amazement( 惊讶 ), she saw Mr. Darcy walk into the room.
He asked about her well-being, and she answered him with cold politeness.
He sat down for a few moments, but soon stood up and began walking about the room.
Elizabeth was surprised, but did not say a word.
After a silence of several minutes, he came toward her, obviously upset, and began:
“In vain( 徒劳 ) I have struggled.
It will not do.
My feelings( 感受 ) will not be repressed( 被压抑 ).
You must allow me to tell you how greatly I admire and love you.”
Elizabeth’s astonishment( 惊讶 ) was indescribable.
She stared, blushed( 脸红 ), and was silent.
This he considered to be sufficient( 足够的 ) encouragement.
He immediately began to confess( 坦白 ) all that he had felt for her for so long.
He spoke well, but he also spoke of other feelings( 感受 ) besides those of love.
He talked at least as much about personal and family pride as he did about love.

He spoke with warmth about his sense of her inferiority( 低下 ) as compared to his own family background and how he had finally overcome it, not realizing that this type of speech was most unlikely to persuade Elizabeth.
Despite her deeply-rooted dislike, she could not ignore( 忽略 ) the compliment( 赞扬 ) of such a man’s affection.
She was at first sorry for the pain he was about to receive, but after hearing what he had to say, she lost all sense of compassion( 同情 ) in anger.
She tried, however, to compose( 使平静 ) herself to answer him with patience.
He concluded( 结束 ) with expressing to her the strength of his feelings( 感受 ), which he had found impossible to ignore( 忽略 ).
When he expressed his hope that he would now be rewarded by her acceptance of his proposal( 求婚 ) of marriage,
Elizabeth could easily see from his expression that even though he spoke of fear and anxiety, he actually had no doubt about her answer.
This only angered her more, and when he had finished, the color rose into her cheeks, and she said:
“It is common in such cases as this, I believe, to express a sense of gratitude( 感激 ) for the feelings( 感受 ) shown, however unequally( 不公平地 ) they may be returned.
It is natural that gratitude( 感激 ) should be felt, and if I could feel that way, I would now thank you.
But I cannot—I have never wanted your good opinion, and you have certainly given it to me most unwillingly.
I am sorry to have caused pain to anyone.
Those same reasons which have long prevented you from admitting your love, should make this rejection much less disappointing.”
Mr. Darcy, who was leaning( 倚靠 ) against the fireplace with his eyes fixed on her face, seemed to hear her words with equal parts resentment( 怨恨 ) and surprise.
His face became pale with anger, and the confusion( 困惑 ) in his mind was visible( 明显的 ) in every feature( 五官 ).
He was struggling for the appearance of composure( 镇静 ), and would not open his lips until he believed he had achieved it.
The pause was dreadful( 可怕的 ).
Eventually, with a voice of forced calmness, he said:
“And this is all the reply which I am going to receive!
I might, perhaps, ask why you have rejected me with so little attempt at politeness.
But it is of little importance.”
“I might as well ask,” replied she,
“why you chose to tell me that you liked me against your will, against your reason, and even against your character.
Was this insult( 无礼 ) not some excuse for being impolite( 不礼貌的 ), if I was so?
But I have other reasons.
You know I have.
Suppose I felt differently about you—that I had no feelings( 感受 ) at all about you, or even felt affection for you.
Do you think that anything could tempt( 打动 ) me to accept a man who had had any part in ruining, perhaps forever, the happiness of my most beloved( 挚爱的 ) sister?”
She paused, and saw nothing that showed he had any feelings( 感受 ) of remorse( 懊悔 ).
“Can you deny( 否认 ) that you have done so?” she repeated.
With pretended calmness he then replied: “I have no wish to deny( 否认 ) that I did everything in my power to separate my friend from your sister, or that I take delight in my success.
I have been kinder toward him than toward myself.”
Elizabeth refused to show that she had noticed this comment, but its meaning did not escape her.
“But it is not only this incident,” she continued,
“which has caused my dislike.
Long before it occurred, my opinion of you had already been decided.
I received a clear description of your behavior many months ago from Mr. Wickham.
On this subject, what can you have to say?
Through what imaginary act of friendship can you here defend yourself?
Or through what untruth can you here blame others?”
“You take a strong interest in that gentleman’s concerns,” said Darcy, in a less calm tone( 语气 ), and with reddening cheeks.
“Who can help feeling an interest in him, who knows what his misfortunes have been?”
“His misfortunes!” repeated Darcy,
“yes, his misfortunes have been great indeed.”
“And all caused by you,” cried Elizabeth with energy.
“You have forced him to live in his present state of poverty( 贫穷 ).
You have kept from him, during the best years of his life, the means of support which he was owed( 应该给予的 ) and deserved.
You have done all this!
And yet you can react to the mention of his misfortune with contempt( 鄙视 ) and sarcasm( 嘲笑 ).”
“And this,” cried Darcy, as he walked with quick steps across the room,
“is your opinion of me!
I thank you for explaining yourself so fully.
My faults, according to this judgment, are great indeed! But perhaps,” he added, stopping and turning toward her,
“these faults might have been ignored( 被忽略 ), if your pride had not been hurt.
The doubts that have long prevented me from admitting my love were natural and reasonable.
Could you expect me to take pleasure in the inferiority( 低下的 ) of your relations?
—to congratulate myself on joining with a family, whose position in life is so obviously beneath my own?”
Elizabeth felt herself growing angrier every moment, yet she tried her absolute( 绝对的 ) best to speak with composure( 镇静 ) when she said:
“You are mistaken, Mr. Darcy, if you suppose that the way in which you have declared( 宣告 ) your love has affected me in any other way,
than by removing any concerns which I might have felt in refusing you, had you behaved in a more gentlemanlike( 绅士的 ) manner.”
She saw him draw back as she made this comment, but he said nothing, and she continued:
“You could not have made the offer of marriage in any possible way that would have tempted( 劝诱 ) me to accept it.”
Again his astonishment( 惊讶 ) was obvious, and he looked at her with a mixture of disbelief and humiliation( 蒙羞 ).
“You have said quite enough, madam( 女士 ).
I perfectly understand your feelings( 感受 ), and can now only be ashamed of what my own have been.
Forgive me for having taken up so much of your time, and accept my best wishes for your health and happiness.”
With these words he hastily( 匆忙地 ) left the room, and Elizabeth heard him the next moment open the front door and leave the house.
The tumult( 波动 ) in her mind was now painfully great.
She did not know how to support herself, and from actual weakness sat down and cried for half an hour.
Her astonishment( 惊讶 ), as she reflected on what had happened, increased each time she reviewed it.
She remained in a very agitated( 心烦的 ) state until Charlotte returned.
Feeling how unfit she was to engage( 参与到 ) in conversation, she hurried away to her room.

question.cn: 在Mr. Darcy走进房间之后，他说了什么？
question.en: What did Mr. Darcy say after he walked into the room?

options.en: That he wanted Elizabeth to leave as soon as possible.
That he was in love with Jane  for a long time.
That he admired and loved Elizabeth.

analysis: 文中Darcy走进房间后说到：“In vain I have struggled. It will not do. My feelings will not be repressed. You must allow me to tell you how greatly I admire and love you.” 所以选C。

question.cn: Elizabeth对于Mr. Darcy的求婚反应是怎样的？
question.en: How was Elizabeth's reaction towards Mr. Darcy's proposal?

options.cn: 她说她需要更多的时间考虑。
options.en: She said she needed more time to think about it.

analysis: 文中Elizabeth说到：“Those same reasons which have long prevented you from admitting your love, should make this rejection much less disappointing.”所以选A。

question.cn: Mr. Darcy离开房间时心情是怎样的？
question.en: How did Mr. Darcy feel when he left the room?

analysis: 文中Mr. Darcy最后说道：“I perfectly understand your feelings, and can now only be ashamed of what my own have been.”由此可知选择A。
